results.title: Clash of the titans
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Charles H. Schneer, Ray Harryhausen and Desmond Davis
results.brief_description: Harry Hamlin stars in this film as Perseus, the Greek mythological character, a gifted impetuous youth, sent on a heroic quest. His mission is to fight the deadly creature Kraken, a towering sea monster that is the last of the powerful Titans. If Perseus succeeds he will win the hand of the beautiful Andromeda, an imprisoned princess, and gain the ownership of half the kingdom. Having embarked on his quest, Perseus is aided by Pegasus, the winged horse and Ammon, a benevolent playwright. Laurence Olivier stars as the God Zeus and Maggie Smith as Thetis, a Greek Goddess with magical powers. Ray Harryhausen (who worked on Jason and the Argonauts) utilised his skills and experience to create stop animation for many sequences, which to modern CGI eyes can seem quite dated. Some impressive cinematography is let down by the clunky dialogue and inexpressive face of lead Harry Hamlin but the film is fun and provides a background to the wonderful world of Greek mythology. Conceived in the wake of the phenomenal success of “Star Wars”, “Clash of the titans” did not reach its expected audience who were flooding instead to the thrills of “Raiders of the lost ark”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Charles H. Schneer, Ray Harryhausen and Desmond Davis

results.title: Clash of the carnivores. Window on the wild
results.brief_description: Clash of the carnivores examines the Tasmanian Devil, Tiger Quoll and Eastern Quoll which once ranged across mainland Australia but are now only found in the rugged regions of Tasmania. The competition for a limited food supply is fierce with some unexpected battles and alliances. Healesville Sanctuary features in “Window on the wild” where studies are being undertaken into the lifestyle of nocturnal animals such as the Eastern-barred bandicoot. The sanctuary provides an ideal study locale in addition to a refuge for these highly endangered species.

results.title: Clash by night
results.creator_credit: RKO Radio Pictures, Harriet Parsons and Fritz Lang
results.brief_description: Barbara Stanwyck again plays the femme fatale, with her usual flair, in this adaptation of Clifford Odets’ Broadway play. Mae Doyle returns to Monterey, California, after seeking a life of adventure in the city. Disillusioned and bitter, she forms a relationship with her brother Joe’s friend Jerry (Paul Douglas). A quiet fisherman, Jerry is a decent hardworking husband, but Mae is drawn into an illicit affair with her husband’s friend Earl Pfeiffer (Robert Ryan). Marilyn Monroe makes a brief but memorable appearance as a young girl. “Clash by night” is the age-old story of the “Eternal Triangle” where one woman must choose between two men.

results.title: Clarence River district: moving memories 1920s-1970s
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Take a nostalgic journey back in time to the north coast of New South Wales as depicted in this wonderful collection of historical footage from home movies, documentaries, newsreels and feature film excerpts from the 1920s to the 1970s selected from the National Film and Sound Archive Collection and compiled by Ruth Hill. Focussing on the Clarence River District and the towns of Grafton, Inverell, Coffs Harbour, Casino, Lismore, Tenterfield, Iluka, Glen Innes, Maclean and Moree, the program is segmented into decades allowing the viewer to see towns change and evolve over a 50 year period. Entertaining and informative, the video provides a social commentary of Australian lifestyle, industries and landscape, highlighting such events as the Grafton Jacaranda Festival, street parades at Inverell and Casino, the Annual Flower Show at Lismore, centenary celebrations for both Maclean and Coff’s Harbour and royal celebrations for Queen Elizabeth’s coronation. Also includes footage of some of the industries which have progressed and developed in the district and along the river - oyster farms, fishing, dairying, cane-cutting and timber. Contains sepia, black and white, and colour footage with original commentary retained and music added to the silent segments.

results.title: Clarence and Angel
results.brief_description: Clarence, a black 12-year-old from a migrant family, goes to school for the first time in New York City. Although bright he cannot read and reacts furiously to taunts from other students. At school he meets Angel, a hyperactive wildly imaginative Puerto Rican boy, who misbehaves because he finishes his work so fast he gets restless while the other students work. Clarence and Angel become friends and Angel takes on the responsibility of teaching Clarence to read.

results.title: Clara Gibbings
results.creator_credit: Efftee Film Productions and F.W. Thring
results.brief_description: This production was adapted from the play of the same name and remained basically a filmed stage play. Dorothy Brunton plays Clara Gibbings, the proprietor of a London pub, who discovers that she is the legitimate but abandoned daughter of the Earl of Dunmoor. She launches herself into high society but soon grows disillusioned and decides to return to the fresh air of her own class. A young aristocrat, Errol, has meanwhile learnt to respect Clara and to see his own decadent life in a new light. Impulsively he proposes marriage and they depart for Australia.

results.title: Clara [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Film Camp, Film Victoria, Philippa Campey and Van Sowerine
results.brief_description: An expressive although wordless evocation of a child’s grief, “Clara” uses silicone models and stop motion animation to portray a young girl’s reactions to the death of someone close. (Awards: Chicago International Film festival 2005, Best Animated Film, Cannes Film Festival 2005, Special Mention Best Short Film category)

results.title: Clamshell Apple Laptop
results.brief_description: You probably know what this is, but not what it’s called. Technically it’s the Apple iBook G3 but they’re better known as ‘Clamshells’ because of their curved, colourful design. Introduced in the late 1990s, these fashionable laptops reflected early attempts to offer personalisation through its range of vibrant colours, which also made them stand out in film and TV. In Legally Blonde (2001), Reece Witherspoon’s character is seen lining up to buy one and using it later in class. Sure, this is likely product placement, but it reflects how the entry level computer was targeted at the education market. It was also the first mass consumer product to have WiFi built in. We maintain a large collection of this kind of legacy equipment for use in digital archaeology and preservation of early interactive educational products and artworks.

results.title: Claire of the moon
results.creator_credit: Demi-Monde Productions, Pam Kuri and Nicole Conn
results.brief_description: Two successful writers—a promiscuous heterosexual novelist and a brooding lesbian sex therapist—are assigned a cabin together on a writer’s retreat for women. The two women are total opposites and argue constantly about their different philosophical and sexual orientations. Yet underlying their animosity is a growing sexual tension which, after much angst and rhetoric is finally consummated. Overly earnest in its intellectual attempts to explore female sexuality, “Claire of the moon” fails to engage the viewer on an emotional level. The long-awaited ‘climatic’ sex scene at the film’s conclusion only partially makes up for the tiresome talk-fest that precedes it. Cast includes Trisha Todd and Karen Trumbo.

results.title: Clair de Terre = Earth Light
results.brief_description:
Pierre lives alone with his father in Le Marais district of Paris. He constantly thinks of Tunisia where his mother died when he was only five years old. He finally manages to travel accross to the country of his birth and meets Madame Lariviere, a former friend of the family.

Credits: Director, Guy Gilles ; writers, Guy Gilles ; photography, Guy Gilles, Philippe Rousselot ; music, Jean-Pierre Stora.
Cast: Edwige Feuillere, Annie Girardot, Patrick Jouanne, Roger Hanin, Micheline Presle, Elina Labourdette.
